title: Producing a &'a T does not entail T: 'a in the eye of the compiler

labels.name: T-types
labels.description: Relevant to the types team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code where rustc fails to recognize that  `deref<'a>(&'a Outer) -> &'a Inner` implies that `Inner: 'a`.

The goal of this code is to provide a newtype wrapper around nested smart pointers such as `Rc<bumpalo::boxed::Box<'a, T>>` that is able to `Deref<Target=T>`. In that context, `Rc` is the outer type and `bumpalo::boxed::Box` the inner type.

```rust
use core::ops::Deref;

pub struct Nested<Outer> {
    outer: Outer,
}

impl<T, Outer, Inner> Deref for Nested<Outer>
where
    Outer: Deref<Target = Inner>,
    Inner: Deref<Target = T> + ?Sized,
    T: ?Sized,
{
    type Target = T;

    #[inline]
    fn deref<'a>(&'a self) -> &'a T {
        let outer: &'a Outer = &self.outer;
        let inner: &'a Inner = Deref::deref(outer);
        let x: &'a T = Deref::deref(inner);
        x
    }
}
```

I expected to see this happen: AFAICT this code should compile.

Instead, this happened: rustc rejects the code with the following error:
```
Compiling playground v0.0.1 (/playground)
error[[E0309]](https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/error_codes/E0309.html): the parameter type `Inner` may not live long enough
  --> src/lib.rs:18:20
   |
18 |         let inner: &'a Inner = Deref::deref(outer);
   |                    ^^^^^^^^^ ...so that the type `Inner` will meet its required lifetime bounds
   |
help: consider adding an explicit lifetime bound...
   |
10 |     Inner: Deref<Target = T> + ?Sized + 'a,
   |                                       ++++
```

### Meta
